D1F29A87FBB441B69DF3246DF77F40CE.description:
Analyze decisions and strategies using probability
concepts. For example, product testing, medical testing, pulling a
hockey goalie at the end of a game. ‚òÖ

E2AB8223210E4D5BB270409ADFD879C9.description: Use probability to evaluate outcomes of decisions. ‚òÖ¬†

162DD008B800446E837C708B08B505ED.description:
Apply the Addition Rule, ùëÉùëÉ(ùê¥ùê¥ ùëúùëúùëúùëú ùêµùêµ) = ùëÉùëÉ(ùê¥ùê¥) + ùëÉùëÉ(ùêµùêµ) ‚àí
ùëÉùëÉ(ùê¥ùê¥ ùëéùëéùëéùëéùëéùëé ùêµùêµ), and interpret the answer in terms of the model. ‚òÖ

C3D2A00F0ACE4E488005170450A1B420.description:
Find the conditional probability of ùê¥ùê¥ given ùêµùêµ as the fraction
of ùêµùêµ‚Ä≤ùë†ùë† outcomes that also belong to ùê¥ùê¥ and interpret the answer in terms
of the model. ‚òÖ

0984285077C948F39D0BB6A50B21FA78.description:
Use the rules of probability to compute probabilities of compound events in a
uniform probability model. ‚òÖ

7577013164F744F694D5B5AF085358E6.description:
Recognize and explain the concepts of conditional
probability and independence in everyday language and everyday
situations. For example, compare the chance of having lung cancer if
you are a smoker with the chance of being a smoker if you have lung
cancer. ‚òÖ

7DE1EE7C382A42508020CF49C594F978.description:
Construct and interpret two-way frequency tables of data
when two categories are associated with each object being classified.
Use the two-way table as a sample space to decide if events are
independent and to approximate conditional probabilities. For example,
collect data from a random sample of students in your school on their
favorite subject among mathematics, science, and English. Estimate the
probability that a randomly selected student from your school will favor
science given that the student is in tenth grade. Do the same for other
subjects and compare the results. ‚òÖ

D173DC36D51B48D18B92F3B1C3A735CF.description:
Understand the conditional probability of ùê¥ùê¥ given ùêµùêµ as ùëÉùëÉ(ùê¥ùê¥ ùëéùëéùëéùëéùëéùëé ùêµùêµ)
ùëÉùëÉ(ùêµùêµ) , and interpret independence of ùê¥ùê¥ and ùêµùêµ as saying that the
conditional probability of ùê¥ùê¥ given ùêµùêµ is the same as the probability of ùê¥ùê¥,
and the conditional probability of ùêµùêµ given ùê¥ùê¥ is the same as the
probability of ùêµùêµ.‚òÖ

ABBC0855915B4CAFA783666364984A62.description:
Understand that two events ùê¥ùê¥ and ùêµùêµ are independent if the
probability of ùê¥ùê¥ and ùêµùêµ occurring together is the product of their
probabilities and use this characterization to determine if they are
independent. ‚òÖ

CF3ECC66BDCF41048FFDEBDDF4B96A61.description:
Describe events as subsets of a sample space (the set of
outcomes) using characteristics (or categories) of the outcomes, or as
unions, intersections, or complements of other events (‚Äúor‚Äù ‚Äúand‚Äù ‚Äúnot‚Äù).
‚òÖ

FBB0DE4F38ED4535919D181D665DAFC5.description: Use independence and conditional probability to interpret data.‚òÖ

73D63E11764A4C5FB45BC45DF705CE98.description: Conditional Probability and the Rules of Probability‚òÖ

8699B693D4AB406BA1F5A6F35B8FEC72.description:
Apply geometric methods to solve design problems. For
example, designing an object or structure to satisfy physical constraints
or minimize cost; working with typographic grid systems based on ratios.
‚òÖ

AC468DFDAE77447D8B4B0117C4B42DD6.description:
Apply concepts of density based on area and volume in
modeling situations. For example, persons per square mile, BTUs per
cubic foot. ‚òÖ

773FB55985524417819552DF965F461F.description:
Use geometric shapes, their measures, and their properties to
describe and explain objects. For example, modeling a tree trunk as a cylinder.
‚òÖ

435A9880098E40718FC58A06DE24A07A.description: Apply geometric concepts with modeling situations.¬†¬†

AAE6C711E4AC4706B0131102BA0E3DF7.description:
Identify the shapes of two-dimensional cross-sections of
three-dimensional objects, and identify three-dimensional objects
generated by rotations of two-dimensional objects.¬†

6701584F83324674BEBA883E883DD957.description:
Visualize relationships between two-dimensional and three-dimensional
objects.

0733D564BCA14DBFA7EEE01735F3079B.description:
Use volume formulas for cylinders, pyramids, cones, and
spheres to solve problems. ‚òÖ

3FC22369C25942708DE9FCE88700067E.description:
Give an informal argument for the formulas for the
circumference of a circle, area of a circle, volume of a cylinder, pyramid,
and cone.

FBF99DECA1F44D919F119909559A4FBA.description: Explain volume formulas and use them to solve problems.¬†

314DB2CA65F34923A135F95666BE393B.description:
Use coordinates to compute perimeters of polygons and
areas of triangles and rectangles. For example, use the distance
formula to calculate the distance between the two points. ‚òÖ

EFCC43E438844383B8EF080D27545E19.description:
Find the point on a directed line segment between two
given points that partitions the segment in a given ratio.

3FE4DABB551E42EBA427746F0A2FC828.description:
Prove the slope criteria for parallel and perpendicular
lines and use them to solve geometric problems. For example, find the
equation of a line parallel or perpendicular to a given line that passes
through a given point.

5D4956909EFF494C8E5CA9B3EAEE0358.description:
Use coordinate geometry to prove simple geometric
theorems. For example, prove or disprove that a figure defined by four
given points in the coordinate plane is a rectangle.

AB47ED3DF6C049CBADD8FEE2AD850246.description: Use coordinates to prove simple geometric theorems algebraically.

9BE7603A3F664DEDAE18B0D2F708E675.description:
Derive the equation of a circle of given center and radius
using the Pythagorean Theorem; complete the square to find the center
and radius of a circle given by an equation.

1C837644368E4E6490BCDA10BCDFC951.description:
Translate between the geometric description and the equation for a conic
section.

77124EAE224B4DD583C36B589EAFABA9.description:
Derive using similarity the fact that the length of the arc
intercepted by an angle is proportional to the radius and define the
radian measure of the angle as the constant of proportionality; derive
the formula for the area of a sector.

B05E57242090438C91EF130B1ACF5F5B.description: Find arc lengths and areas of sectors of circles.

ED1144B581EB4D26871F9C1587583C04.description:
Construct the inscribed and circumscribed circles of a
triangle with technology, and investigate properties of a quadrilateral
inscribed in a circle.

ACD389D64FDA4F8498DBAF8A545A45B0.description:
Identify and describe relationships among inscribed angles,
radii, and chords. Include the relationship between central, inscribed,
and circumscribed angles; inscribed angles on a diameter are right
angles; the radius of a circle is perpendicular to the tangent where the
radius intersects the circle.

7E3E105288BE49B1973A44ED6BF8CC9A.description: Prove that all circles are similar.¬†

61046D23794A493DB83053739D7EE88F.description: Understand and apply theorems about circles.

4CF9E408D6304296A489421A80B40A4F.description:
Use trigonometric ratios and the Pythagorean Theorem to
solve right triangles in applied problems, including special right triangles.
‚òÖ

03809D4F1EF645A6A1DD7755C1E8E814.description:
Explain and use the relationship between the sine and
cosine of complementary angles.

57B5054EAC654BA6A83E046796327372.description:
Define trigonometric ratios using similar triangle ratios and
the ratios of corresponding side lengths.

58A200AC28CB41AEA9387EFCC5403B62.description: Define trigonometric ratios and solve problems involving right triangles.

FA97D4F96D2D49FAA5F7E73134F6BA73.description:
Use congruence and similarity criteria for triangles to
solve problems and to prove relationships in geometric figures.

AEA2C362A97448588AC6A39F4D74CA3C.description:
Prove theorems about triangles. Theorems include: a line
parallel to one side of a triangle divides the other two proportionally, and
conversely; the Pythagorean Theorem proved using triangle similarity.¬†

2861465D697949C0B197AB95992CF23F.description: Prove and apply theorems involving similarity.

F95C6E4B35B04533804E12CA8C88779E.description:
Use the properties of similarity transformations to
establish the AA criterion for two triangles to be similar.

B8A1F7641CF44883A74E7AF6E16C9674.description:
Given two figures, use the definition of similarity in terms
of similarity transformations to decide if they are similar; explain using
similarity transformations the meaning of similarity for triangles as the
equality of all corresponding pairs of angles and the proportionality of all
corresponding pairs of sides.

35E5ABAB78194FFAB43AD1F9E043D4AE.description:
The dilation of a line segment is longer or shorter in the ratio
given by the scale factor.

2A6B2810CE7E4CA6B90A1DBE70879ED0.description:
A dilation takes a line not passing through the center of the
dilation to a parallel line and leaves a line passing through the
center unchanged.

34B12131C95D41EB97AD29C7815CBEDD.description:
Verify experimentally the properties of dilations given by a
center and a scale factor:

E163958708D54B519E49E4E676D14B22.description: Understand similarity in terms of similarity transformations.¬†

0115E5D37C5E41ED8B10D403DF7225F0.description:
Construct an equilateral triangle, a square, and a regular
hexagon inscribed in a circle.

2E05DFEEAF4F41F4823D7DE74833AF9A.description:
Make formal geometric constructions with a variety of
tools and methods (compass and straightedge, string, reflective devices,
paper folding, dynamic geometric software, etc.). Copying a segment;
copying an angle; bisecting a segment; bisecting an angle; constructing
perpendicular lines, including the perpendicular bisector of a line
segment; and constructing a line parallel to a given line through a point
not on the line.

886A641DD17D448DB77C4DFA3EF36A5C.description:
Prove theorems about parallelograms. Theorems include
opposite sides are congruent, opposite angles are congruent, the
diagonals of a parallelogram bisect each other, and conversely,
rectangles are parallelograms with congruent diagonals.

26736E4F4BFC45288B649D4802999FA2.description:
Prove theorems about triangles. Theorems include
measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180; base angles of
isosceles triangles are congruent; the segment joining midpoints of two
sides of a triangle is parallel to the third side and half the length; the
medians of a triangle meet at a point.

8112160A596340E78A484F2EE2BFD66B.description:
Prove theorems about lines and angles. Theorems include
vertical angles are congruent; when a transversal crosses parallel lines,
alternate interior angles are congruent and corresponding angles are
congruent; points on a perpendicular bisector of a line segment are
exactly those equidistant from the segment‚Äôs endpoints.

4DA3BEB8ADF84EE1906F893BEEB6159A.description:
Explain how the criteria for triangle congruence (ASA,
SAS, and SSS) follow from the definition of congruence in terms of rigid
motions.

60F3D188336C4F0A9EB02322D5A21E22.description:
Use the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions
to show that two triangles are congruent if and only if corresponding
pairs of sides and corresponding pairs of angles are congruent.

D8B7E15312864E4C96376C6945C13ADA.description:
Use geometric descriptions of rigid motions to transform
figures and to predict the effect of a given rigid motion on a given figure;
given two figures, use the definition of congruence in terms of rigid
motions to decide if they are congruent.

49B828D5F0684DBE9ED4E169ECF31107.description: Understand congruence in terms of rigid motions.

E6216F3F91B54A8C91031870CD74A4E7.description:
Given a geometric figure and a rotation, reflection, or
translation, draw the transformed figure. Specify a sequence of
transformations that will carry a given figure onto another. For example,
using graph paper, tracing paper, or geometry software.

CAEBE56FFE4148B1A96CB573FBA467C5.description:
Develop definitions of rotations, reflections, and
translations in terms of angles, circles, perpendicular lines, parallel lines,
and line segments.

87225D013FD745AFA2B9A5E00ADDFE19.description:
Given a rectangle, parallelogram, trapezoid, or regular
polygon, describe the rotations and reflections that carry it onto itself.

CC271BF7A169471A98D7BD2CE3DD5E34.description:
Represent transformations in the plane using geometry
software; describe transformations as functions that take points in the
plane as inputs and give other points as outputs. Compare
transformations that preserve distance and angle to those that do not.
For example, translation versus horizontal stretch).

ADDD4A4A9F1945EB86DB4C6512777AF5.description:
Know precise definitions of angle, circle, perpendicular line,
parallel line, and line segment, based on the undefined notions of point,
line, distance along a line, and distance around a circular arc.¬†

2B570AC957994943AA078FB626BB5966.description: Experiment with transformations in the plane.
